articles.title: Trump Calls for ‘New Leadership’ in Iran, Says ‘Sick Man’ Ayatollah Ali Khamenei Has Made Nation ‘Worst Place to Live’
articles.content:
President Donald Trump, responding to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei’s attempt to blame him for recent protester deaths, slammed the Iranian Supreme Leader as a “sick man” and called for “new leadership,” declaring: “His country is the worst place to live anywhere in the world because of poor leadership.”

The post Trump Calls for ‘New Leadership’ in Iran, Says ‘Sick Man’ Ayatollah Ali Khamenei Has Made Nation ‘Worst Place to Live’ appeared first on Breitbart.

articles.title: "This Regime Will Fall": Director Jafar Panahi on Deadly Iran Protests & Filmmaking Under Censorship
articles.content:
With Iran gripped by nationwide protests that activists say have left at least 2,600 people dead, we recently spoke with renowned Iranian filmmaker Jafar Panahi, whose latest film, It Was Just an Accident, was shot entirely in secret inside Iran and won the Palme d’Or at the 2025 Cannes Film Festival. The film has since been shortlisted for an Oscar in the international feature category. Panahi dedicated a recent New York Film Critics Circle Award to Iranian protesters.

It Was Just an Accident centers on a group of former prisoners who kidnap a man they believe was their interrogator and grapple with whether to exact revenge, and Panahi says the film drew directly from his own experience with state violence and repression. Panahi has been repeatedly arrested in Iran, served prison sentences, and was recently sentenced in absentia to an additional year in prison and a two-year travel ban.

In an extended interview, Pahani discussed the protests in Iran, fighting against censorship, and the risk of prolonged cycles of violence. “I have always said this regime will fall. It is impossible for it to not fall, because it’s a failed state in every sense,” he said. “What I care about is the future of my country. I want the country to stand. I want there to be peace, and I want our children and the children of our children to not be facing bullets.” He was interpreted by Sheida Dayani.

articles.title: "Empire in Decline": Historian Alfred McCoy on U.S. Aggression in Venezuela, Iran & Beyond
articles.content:
As President Trump threatens Iran, Venezuela, Mexico, Greenland and more, renowned historian Alfred McCoy says the United States is “an empire in decline,” following a predictable pattern of militarism abroad and political instability at home as it loses power and influence on the world stage. “American politics become increasingly contorted and irrational,” says McCoy. “I think the thing to do is to realize that we are an empire in decline, … and it will continue for another decade or two, until American power finally slips away.”

McCoy just published his latest book, Cold War on Five Continents: A Global History of Empire and Espionage, on the impact of U.S.-Soviet imperial proxy wars in Africa, Asia and Latin America.

articles.title: "State of Siege": Iran Protest Death Toll Rises to 2,000 After U.S. Sanctions Spawn Economic Crisis
articles.content:
Iran has said it’s ready for “war” or dialogue after President Trump said the U.S. was considering “very strong options” to intervene if Iran’s security forces kill anti-government protesters in an ongoing crackdown. Vali Nasr, professor at Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, says the U.S. “can wage full-scale war on Iran — which President Trump does not seem to be eager to do — or it can hope to squeeze Iran economically in order to create political unrest in Iran.”

This comes as at least 648 people have been killed since protests broke out in late December, according to the Norway-based group Iran Human Rights, and over 10,000 people have been arrested. Iranian officials say the number of dead could be as high as 2,000.

articles.title: "This Is Our Hemisphere": Report from Colombia on Trump's Escalating Threats to the Region
articles.content:
Following his attack on Venezuela and the abduction of Nicolás Maduro, President Donald Trump has escalated his threats against Colombia and claimed without evidence that President Gustavo Petro is involved in cocaine trafficking. Trump and others in his administration have also threatened military action against Cuba, Greenland, Iran and Mexico in recent days.

Manuel Rozental, a Colombian physician and activist with more than 40 years of involvement in grassroots political organizing, tells Democracy Now! that Trump’s attacks on Petro are lies. The former guerrilla “has seized more cocaine than any other government in the past,” says Rozental. “President Petro is not a drug trafficker. President Petro has been a victim of drug mafias and their allies.”

summary:
COMMON GROUND
The Iran crisis is characterized by significant internal unrest and protests. Both perspectives acknowledge that these protests are met with a forceful crackdown by the Iranian regime, resulting in a rising death toll. It is also recognized that the United States is involved in the situation through various means, including sanctions and statements regarding support for protesters, and that there is mutual condemnation between the Iranian leadership and U.S. officials.

THE CASE IN FAVOR
The narrative advocating for robust U.S. support to Iranians emphasizes that former President Trump has demonstrated 'unprecedented support' for the Iranian people. This perspective views the current Iranian leadership as a 'terror regime,' arguing for strong U.S. backing to facilitate its overthrow and the establishment of new leadership in the country.

THE CASE AGAINST
Critics argue that the situation in Iran involves a complex interplay of internal repression and international dynamics. This narrative highlights reports of a significant death toll in ongoing protests, with some sources claiming thousands of fatalities and describing the situation as a 'genocide.' Concerns are also raised regarding the Iranian regime's alleged use of radioactive warheads against U.S. troops. While a desire for broader U.S. action against Iran's repression exists across the political spectrum, this perspective also points to the Iranian leadership's characterization of U.S. actions, particularly by former President Trump, as 'criminal,' asserting a need for accountability. The narrative also suggests that U.S. sanctions have contributed to an economic crisis, which in turn has seen protest death tolls rise amid an escalating crackdown. Furthermore, former President Trump's approach is described as unpredictable, with threats of military action that coincide with the regime's intensified efforts to suppress dissent. Some analyses also characterize U.S. actions in the region as 'aggression' contributing to a perceived 'empire in decline.'

OBSERVATIONS ON EMPHASIS
The narrative advocating for robust U.S. support to Iranians primarily focuses on the characterization of the Iranian leadership as a 'terror regime' and highlights the necessity of U.S. backing for its replacement. Conversely, critics and those presenting a broader perspective emphasize the severe humanitarian consequences of the crackdown, specific allegations against the Iranian regime, the impact of U.S. sanctions on the economic crisis, and the Iranian leadership's own criticisms of the U.S. The internal dynamics of dissent and broader implications of U.S. foreign policy are also central to this view.
prompt_used:
ROLE: You are a senior newspaper editor. Your task is to synthesize multiple narratives into a single, high-quality, neutral editorial summary.

TONE GUIDELINES:
- Neutral, precise, and calm.
- Editorial style, not academic. Avoid jargon.
- No moralizing language (e.g., avoid 'unfortunately', 'rightly').
- Do NOT strictly declare one side correct.
- Do NOT mention 'bias', 'sentiment', or 'AI'.
- Use 'The pro-[topic] narrative emphasizes...' or 'Critics argue...' rather than 'User 1 said...'.

TOPIC: Iran Crisis

INPUT DATA:
--- GROUP A: ARTICLES IN FAVOR (SUPPORTING) ---
1. [Latest Political News on Fox News | right] Summary: Jeb Bush heaps praise on Trump’s ‘unprecedented support’ for Iranians 10 years after heated primary
2. [The Daily Wire - Breaking News, Videos & Podcasts | right] Summary: ‘Take Out The Trash’: GOP Senator Urges U.S. Support For Overthrowing Iran’s Terror Regime

--- GROUP B: ARTICLES AGAINST (OPPOSING) ---
1. [New York Post | right] Summary: Michael Goodwin: Trump spared the ayatollah for now— but his options in Iran are still wide open
2. [New York Post | right] Summary: Iranian doctors reportedly say protest death toll over 16K: ‘Genocide under the cover of digital darkness’
3. [The Daily Wire - Breaking News, Videos & Podcasts | right] Summary: Both Sides Of The Aisle Want Broader U.S. Action Against Iran’s Repression
4. [The Daily Wire - Breaking News, Videos & Podcasts | right] Summary: Investigation: Iran Accused Of Using ‘Dirty’ Radioactive Warheads On U.S. Troops In 2020
5. [The Daily Wire - Breaking News, Videos & Podcasts | right] Summary: Morning Brief: Trump Threatens Insurrection Act, Iran On Edge & Senators Scrutinize Abortion Pill
6. [The Daily Wire - Breaking News, Videos & Podcasts | right] Summary: The Fog Of Trump: How Unpredictability Keeps Iran Guessing
7. [The Daily Wire - Breaking News, Videos & Podcasts | right] Summary: Democrats: ICE Is Just Like The Ayatollahs
8. [Breitbart News | right] Summary: Trump Calls for ‘New Leadership’ in Iran, Says ‘Sick Man’ Ayatollah Ali Khamenei Has Made Nation ‘Worst Place to Live’
9. [Breitbart News | right] Summary: Khamenei Celebrates ‘Defeat’ of U.S., Mocks ‘Criminal’ Trump: America Must Be ‘Held Accountable’
10. [Politics | left] Summary: Iran's Leader Calls Trump A 'Criminal' For Backing Protesters
11. [Democracy Now! | left] Summary: Headlines for January 16, 2026
12. [Democracy Now! | left] Summary: "This Regime Will Fall": Director Jafar Panahi on Deadly Iran Protests & Filmmaking Under Censorship
13. [Democracy Now! | left] Summary: Headlines for January 15, 2026
14. [Democracy Now! | left] Summary: Headlines for January 14, 2026
15. [Democracy Now! | left] Summary: "Empire in Decline": Historian Alfred McCoy on U.S. Aggression in Venezuela, Iran & Beyond
16. [Democracy Now! | left] Summary: "State of Siege": Iran Protest Death Toll Rises to 2,000 After U.S. Sanctions Spawn Economic Crisis
17. [Democracy Now! | left] Summary: Headlines for January 13, 2026
18. [Democracy Now! | left] Summary: Iran Escalates Deadly Crackdown on Mass Protests as Trump Threatens to Launch Military Attack
19. [Democracy Now! | left] Summary: Headlines for January 12, 2026
20. [Democracy Now! | left] Summary: Headlines for January  9, 2026
21. [Democracy Now! | left] Summary: "This Is Our Hemisphere": Report from Colombia on Trump's Escalating Threats to the Region
22. [Democracy Now! | left] Summary: Headlines for January  7, 2026
23. [Democracy Now! | left] Summary: Headlines for January  5, 2026


OUTPUT INSTRUCTIONS:
Produce a written summary with the following FOUR clearly labeled sections. IMPORTANT: Do NOT use any markdown formatting (like *, #, **). Output strictly plain text. Do NOT make titles bold. Do NOT use bullet points unless creating a list.

1. COMMON GROUND
   - Identify facts or points agreed upon by both groups.
   - If no obvious agreement, note the shared subject matter factually.

2. THE CASE IN FAVOR
   - Summarize the arguments and focus of the IN FAVOR group.
   - Attribute these views generally to proponents.

3. THE CASE AGAINST
   - Summarize the arguments and focus of the AGAINST group.
   - Attribute these views generally to critics or opponents.

4. OBSERVATIONS ON EMPHASIS
   - Briefly note what each side specifically highlights or omits.
   - Example: 'Supporters focus on economic growth, while opponents focus on environmental risk.'
   - Keep this descriptive.
